climbs.name: Upper Burn to Ecstasy Junior (Burn Variation)

content.description: From the large ledge shared with EJ and the Burn, climb the crack in the face above up to the roof.  At the roof, move to the left and join with EJ's P2.  Finish up EJ's P2 to the top.
content.location: On the large ledge shared with EJ and The Burn.

content.description: From the belay ledge shared with EJ and The Burn, climb the crack in the face up to the roof.  At the roof, traverse out right and around the corner to a small ledge in a corner.  Climb the corner to the top and the shared belay with EJ.
content.protection: Standard trad rack.  Be sure to take plenty of long slings for the traverse.
content.location: On the large ledge shared with EJ and The Burn

content.description: Starts on the face just left of The Burn.  Climb up to a bolt and then continue on the the Ecstasy Junior belay ledge.
content.protection: Standard rack with an emphasis on tiny gear.

content.description:
Start: same as Ecstasy Junior.

#1. Claimb up and right of Ecstasy Junior for about 10 ft. to a steep right facing corner. Climb the corner, then step left to an easy vegetated crack.  Follow this crack to a tree that lies next to a large roof. (The continuation of the crack turns into Ecstasy: Vegetable Variation) (70 ft.)

#2. Traverse out right beneath the roof. When the overhang becomes double tiered pull the roof to a right facing corner. Follow the corner to the top (60 ft.)
content.protection: Standard Senaca rack - med and med/large chocks mostly..

climbs.name: Mr. No Wrench
climbs.fa: Eddie Begoon, George Powell, & Tom Cecil, 1993

content.description: Climb interesting and atypical Seneca face features past 3 bolts and a few pieces of gear to the base of the roof. Clip the bolt at the roof and make a series of hard and bouldery moves to pull the lip. Continue up the face past two more bolts to a bolt anchor.
content.location: Climb the first pitch of Ecstasy Jr., The Burn, or Sunshine. From the ledge traverse left to the bolt line below the obvious roof just right of Ecstasy Jr. Vegetable Variation.

content.description: Thin holds and sparse gear. The climb starts just right of the vegetated ramp below Ecstasy Jr. and directly below the bolt on Sunshine. Climb straight up towards the bolt, through small edges and side pulls. The route joins Sunshine a little bit below the bolt.  Climb the rest of Sunshine to finish. The guide book rates it 5.11d R/X. The moves are strenuous and the little gear you get can be tricky to place.  Usually done as a top rope, but a fun and spicy lead.
content.protection: One bolt. Micro stoppers, and micro cams are key. A .2 x4 cam, BD #3 micro stopper and a BD #8 stopper are crucial to cutting down the runout through the crux.
content.location: Located just right of the vegetated ramp below Ecstasy Jr. And just left of Sunshine and the Burn. The route starts directly below the bolt on Sunshine

content.description:
Start area same is the same as Ecstasy Junior, on the ramp left of Sunshine.

P1: The original start is the long right-facing ramp to the left of Sunshine (basically shared with the original EJ start). Climb to the ledge with a big pine where many folks start EJ these days. (5.1/5.2)

P2: Continue up some blocky sections and into a small alcove. Move up and left on good holds and pull out around the corner to a large rubble covered ledge with a good size tree (this is where Dirty Harry, Wife's A Bitch, and The Con Man start). (5.4)

P3: Move up a short dirt slope and past some Greenbriar and gain the blocky face with a small chimney on the left side. Climb this to a good ledge. From around here you can belay and then walk/scramble off to the north. Instead of belaying there, you can continue up to the east on somewhat lichen-covered ledges to the area beneath the big orange overhangs (aka the old Hemlock Grove) and make a belay there. You can easily walk off to the north from here. (5.3/5.4)
content.protection: Standard trad rack, no special large gear needed.  A pair of pruners might be nice to tame some of the Greenbriar :-)
content.location: Start area same as Ecstasy Junior.

content.description:
From the top of the 1st pitch of Ecstasy Junior, traverse left to a crack system that becomes a large, right facing corner and has plenty of "vegetables" scattered along it.  Climb the crack and the corner to the top.

A #4 or #5 cam will keep the last 15' or so from becoming R, though it is on fairly easy terrain. There's two ways to finish this: either top out the corner and build a belay in some cracks on the slabby rock in front of you (right of the big overhangs) or continue to the very top and use a tree for your anchor. If you choose the first option, you can walk-off to climbers left, through the old Hemlock Grove and then into the Stairmaster
content.protection: Standard trad rack plus a #4 or #5 cam for some wide stuff up top.
content.location: Top of the first pitch of Ecstasy Junior (EJ).

climbs.name: Ecstasy Junior
climbs.fa: Chris Scoredos, Don Jacobs, Roy Britton

content.description:
This climb makes a nice way to bypass the Stairmaster and gain Luncheon Ledge - the ledge system where

Triple S

and most of the West Face routes are located.

P1: Traverse right on the ledge, then up a crack and ledge system to a spacious ledge with a few trees and rappel rings over

The Burn

(80ft).

P2: Climb the right facing corner system up and around a cave-like feature and V-slot to another spacious ledge with a tree.  Belay here (80ft).
content.location:
Begin about 30 feet to the left of

The Burn

.  Climb a short vegetated ramp to a smallish ledge with a sizable tree (10ft).  Begin the climb here to avoid ropedrag.  Descend by walking through a slot and head north to Luncheon Ledge and Triple S.  You could also rappel from the tree (80ft), then from the anchors over The Burn (100+ feet, 60M rope with stretch required!!).  Do the walkoff, it's safer.

content.description:
Climb GGG to a large ledge at the end of the second pitch (alternatively you can climb a crack up a short wall from the about 3/4 of the way up the Stairmaster to this same point).  Step past some greenbriars and climb the obvious right-facing corner to the roof. Move left about 5 ft or so, place some good gear, and pull the roof to a good stance.  Move up on positive holds and locate a large horizontal crack for a placement right about the point of being runout.  Continue up easy terrain to a ledge below and right of the big orange/white overhangs and build a belay.

Walk-off left to the Old Hemlock Grove.  Alternatively, you could continue up the easy slabby face to the top, belay, and then walk off on the trail up there in the middle area between the SW Buttress and the Main West Face areas.

This is actually a pretty decent line that deserves more traffic.  It just happens to be a little out-of-the-way.
content.protection: Standard rack plus a #4 or #5 cam for the placement up above the roof.
content.location: On a ledge at the end of the second pitch of Gert's Grungy Gully

climbs.name: The Con Man
climbs.fa: Howard Doyle, Eric Janoscrat, Paul Anikis

content.description:
From the right side of the ledge, climb the face up to the small overhang. Work up the weakness at a small tree and gain a small stance.  Up to this point you need to have plugged in whatever gear you might've been able to get because there's nothing for awhile.  Climb the steep and sustained slab above, using the two shallow cracks/runnels to the second overhang.  Pull the overhang to a great stance and gear placements.  Climb the flake and final overhang above, using some large, positive sloper holds at the top.

At the top, you'll find a good ledge where EJ Veggie Variation tops out to your right and the big orange overhangs of the old Hemlock Grove are to your left.  You can sort out a decent belay here.  Walk off left and find the top of the Stairmaster.

Serious props to Doyle and Co for doing this one.  The face climbing just doesn't let up until you get to the overhang.

You can rig a TR on this one from the ledge up above.  Hike up the Stairmaster to the Hemlock Grove and access the ledge.  Rig the anchor just a bit left of where EJ Veggie Variation comes up.  Take a grill brush as it probably needs a scrubbing.
content.protection: Gear to 1".  You won't use much...you'll probably use as much gear in the anchor as the route.  It's an X route.
content.location: On a ledge at the end of the 2nd pitch of Gert's Grungy Gulley.  There is a good size tree here for a belay. The obvious right-facing corner of Dirty Harry/Magnum Force is to the right.  Straight overhead you'll see a big flake stuck in an overhang above a steep face with what looks like good cracks in it (they aren't...basically shallow runnels).

content.description:
The Burn is the first route one comes to after hiking around the corner from the Southern End on one's way up the Stairmaster.  Start on a block with a small tree.

P1: Climb up the face via cracks and through the overhang above to the Ecstasy Junior belay ledge.  Most people stop here but there is a second pitch.

P2: Climb up the face to the right of a corner.

P1: Climb the first half of The Burn to the large horizontal break.  You can also get to this spot by climbing the first pitch of Ecstasy. (length varies depending on if you climb The Burn or Ecstasy).

P2: Traverse left to the vertical crack on Ecstasy Junior and climb this to the big ledge and belay. (40 ft.)

If doing the as a variation to The Burn, you can link both pitches.  Be sure to use a number of long slings or the rope drag from the traverse will be heinous.
content.protection: Standard trad rack. Longer slings (48") recommended.
content.location: Same as The Burn or Ecstasy (your choice of where to start)

content.description:
Climb The Burn to the large horizontal break (optional belay).  Pull up and over the bulge to a stance. Traverse left to a short right-facing corner.  Climb the corner to its top and a good stance.  Traverse left to the  upper part of the EJ crack and finish up this to the large ledge.

Similar to the "Traverse Pitch", you can get to this either by climbing the first half of The Burn or pitch 1 of Ecstasy.  If starting up The Burn, you could do this all in one pitch without too much trouble on rope drag (use long runners as needed).  If climbing up P1 of Ecstasy, it would be wise to do it in two pitches, building a belay at the horizontal break.
content.protection: Standard trad rack; no special gear needed.
content.location: Climb the first half of The Burn or pitch 1 of Ecstasy.

content.description: From the large belay ledge at the top of The Burn and Ecstasy Junior, located the obvious crack that splits the face.  Climb the crack to the roof, plug some gear and pull the roof.  Continue up the unprotected face above to the belay tree shared with EJ.  The hard stuff is pulling the roof and getting established above.  The climbing above is still in the 5.8/5.9 range and exposed with no gear.
content.protection: Standard trad rack.  Good gear to the roof, then nothing much.
content.location: At the large ledge shared with EJ and The Burn.
